title: Dark Freeze-out Cogenesis
summary: This paper proposes a new mechanism for generating the observed dark matter abundance and baryon asymmetry, addressing the coincidence between the two. The thermal freeze-out of dark matter annihilating into meta-stable dark partners sets the dark matter relic abundance while providing the out-of-equilibrium condition for baryogenesis.
methodology: The authors propose a new mechanism where a multi-component dark sector generates the observed dark matter abundance and baryon asymmetry. The thermal freeze-out of dark matter annihilating into meta-stable dark partners sets the dark matter relic abundance while providing the out-of-equilibrium condition for baryogenesis.
research_outcomes: The authors demonstrate that their mechanism can produce the observed coincidence between dark matter and baryon abundances, and provide a novel analytical treatment for dark sector freeze-out.

title: Phase-space wavepacket dynamics of internal conversion via conical intersection: Multi-state quantum Fokker-Planck equation approach
summary: This paper investigates the role of conical intersections in internal conversion processes of photoexcited molecules. The authors employ a multi-state quantum Fokker-Planck equation approach to study wavepacket dynamics on potential energy surfaces, providing a quantitative analysis of the interplay between thermal relaxation and de-excitation dynamics.
methodology: The authors use a multi-state quantum Fokker-Planck equation approach to study wavepacket dynamics on potential energy surfaces. They employ numerical integrations of the MSQFPE using a general-purpose graphics processing unit (GPGPU).
research_outcomes: The authors find that the calculated yields through non-adiabatic transitions are sensitive to the profile of the PESs of the CI model. They also show that the interplay between thermal relaxation and de-excitation dynamics is crucial for understanding internal conversion processes.

title: WIMP search from XMASS-I fiducial volume data with background prediction
summary: This paper presents a WIMP search using the XMASS-I detector, focusing on direct detection of dark matter particles. The research uses background prediction and Monte Carlo simulations to evaluate the presence of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs). However, machine learning or AI methods are not employed in this study.
methodology: The methodology involves data reduction using standard cuts, timing-based reconstruction cuts, and observed photo-electron based reconstruction cuts. Background evaluation is performed using Geant4-based Monte Carlo simulations.
research_outcomes: A 90% confidence level upper limit on the spin-independent WIMP-nucleon cross section of 2.2×10−44 cm2 for a WIMP mass of 60 GeV/c2 was derived.

title: Introduction to Semi-Classical Analysis for Digital Errors of Qubit in Quantum Processor
summary: This paper surveys the progress of modeling quantum noise effects that information theorists may face in the future, focusing on nontrivial errors. It explains a channel error model to represent strange properties of error probability due to new quantum noise and provides specific examples.
methodology: The authors use semi-classical analysis to study digital errors of qubits in quantum processors, classifying quantum noise effects by physical phenomena and providing an information theoretic representation.
research_outcomes: The paper presents a new type of error, 'Nonlinear error', which is caused by the dependence of error probability on the number of qubits. It also introduces concrete physical phenomena for such features discussed in physics articles.

title: The Influence of Chromium Thermal-Diffusion-Based Doping on the Spatial Distribution of Luminescence Intensity in ZnSe
summary: This paper investigates the effects of chromium thermal-diffusion-based doping on the spatial distribution of luminescence intensity in ZnSe crystals. The study finds that the doping process leads to the formation of at least two types of defective-impurity centers, which are associated with green and yellow bands. However, machine learning or artificial intelligence methods are not used in this research.
methodology: The authors use a combination of experimental techniques, including two-photon excitation microscopy and absorption measurements, to study the spatial distribution of luminescence intensity in ZnSe crystals doped with chromium.
research_outcomes: The study finds that the doping process leads to the formation of at least two types of defective-impurity centers, which are associated with green and yellow bands. The authors also observe a complex behavior in the spatial distribution of luminescence intensity.

title: A simple Cherenkov detector for educational purposes
summary: This paper presents a low-cost, educational Cherenkov detector constructed from a plastic trash bin and a photo multiplier tube. The detector is used to observe cosmic rays and demonstrates the principle of Cherenkov radiation.
methodology: The detector construction involves using a barrel with reflective inner surfaces to channel light into photon counting detectors, and a simple setup to keep the PMT above water level.
research_outcomes: The detector successfully observes cosmic rays and demonstrates Cherenkov radiation. The setup can be used for educational purposes and has potential for improvement with additional materials and calibration.

title: Predicting electron spin decoherence with a many-body first-principles approach
summary: This paper presents a many-body theory of spin relaxation and develops precise ab initio calculations of phonon-induced spin decoherence in semiconductors. The authors use a formalism that unifies the modeling of two main sources of phonon-induced spin decoherence, enabling accurate predictions of spin relaxation and precession in semiconductors.
methodology: The authors use a many-body first-principles approach to calculate the phonon-dressed vertex of the spin-spin correlation function. They derive a Bethe-Salpeter equation for the phonon-dressed spin vertex and compute the macroscopic SRTs in Eq. (2) as a function of temperature.
statistics: The authors use statistical methods, including the Kubo formula and the ladder vertex correction, to calculate the spin relaxation times and precession rates.
research_outcomes: The paper presents accurate predictions of spin decoherence in semiconductors, with excellent agreement with experiments. The authors demonstrate that their formalism can capture both EY and DP mechanisms, which are important for different types of materials.
sources_of_inspiration: Kim et al. (rigorously proved that the Boltzmann equation is equivalent to the ladder vertex correction to the conductivity)

title: Dynamical Phase Transition from Nonequilibrium Dynamics of Dark Solitons
summary: This paper discusses a novel dynamical phase transition for superfluids, where the authors identify a critical temperature above which the system relaxes to equilibrium by producing sound waves. The research focuses on the non-equilibrium dynamics of dark solitons and their decay mechanisms, with implications for understanding the behavior of superfluids in various regimes.
methodology: The authors use a combination of analytical and numerical methods to study the dynamics of dark solitons in two classes of theories: dissipative Gross-Pitaevskii equation (GPE) and holographic superfluid. They examine the temperature dependence of the decay mechanisms and identify a critical temperature above which the system relaxes to equilibrium.
research_outcomes: The authors find that for temperatures above the critical temperature, dark solitons directly decay into sound waves, while below this temperature an intermediate phase with a finite density of vortices emerges. They also identify parallels between holographic superfluids and ultracold atomic gases in the BEC and BCS regimes.

title: A Miniature Fabry Perot Sensor for Twist/Rotation, Strain and Temperature Measurements Based on a Four-Core Fiber
summary: This paper presents a novel miniature Fabry-Perot twist/rotation sensor using a four-core fiber and quadruple interferometer setup. The sensor is designed to measure twist/rotation, strain, and temperature with high sensitivity and compactness.
methodology: The sensor uses a four-core fiber with an asymmetrical microstructure that modulates the path lengths of all four interferometers simultaneously when rotated.
research_outcomes: The sensor demonstrates high sensitivity and accuracy in measuring twist/rotation, strain, and temperature. It has potential applications in various industrial fields.

title: Electricity Stealing Time Recognition Method Based on Difference and K-means Clustering
summary: This paper proposes a method to determine the time of electricity stealing by combining difference algorithm and K-means clustering. The method is based on the fluctuation rate of electric quantity, which helps choose a suitable algorithm. For users with low fluctuation rates, the difference algorithm is used, while for those with high fluctuation rates, K-means clustering is employed.
methodology: The methodology involves data pre-processing to fill in missing values through linear interpolation, followed by calculating the fluctuation rate of electric quantity. Based on this rate, either the difference algorithm or K-means clustering is applied to identify the stealing time.
research_outcomes: The proposed method can correctly determine the power-stealing time for most users, with an error within one or two days. It also shows that using the difference algorithm for users with low fluctuation rates can save computing resources compared to K-means clustering.

title: Holographic CBK Relation
summary: This paper studies the non-perturbative terms in the Crewther-Broadhurst-Kataev (CBK) relation using a holographic dual theory. The authors derive an exact holographic expression for the Bjorken function and the three-point axial-vector-vector correlation function, showing that they agree with the one-loop expressions obtained in conformal field theories.
methodology: The authors use a bottom-up approach to holographic QCD, adopting the model proposed in Ref. [17] amended by the 5D Chen-Simons term required to study the 4D correlation functions exhibiting the axial anomaly.
research_outcomes: The paper shows that the CBK relation is satisfied at the non-perturbative level, and provides an exact holographic expression for the Bjorken function and the three-point axial-vector-vector correlation function.

title: Magnetic Skyrmions in FePt Square-Based Nanoparticles Around Room-Temperature
summary: This paper studies the formation of magnetic skyrmions around room-temperature in square-based parallelepiped magnetic FePt nanoparticles using micromagnetic simulations. The research focuses on understanding how the confined nature of geometry affects skyrmion creation-stabilization and their size and energetics.
methodology: Micromagnetic Finite Differences (FD) calculations were conducted using Mumax3 Finite Differences software to solve the Landau-Lifshitz-Gilbert equation.
research_outcomes: The study found that stable skyrmions can be created at temperatures around 300 K in FePt nanoparticles with parallelepiped geometry of square base, without chiral interactions like Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya (DM) or its interfacial analogue (iDM).
sources_of_inspiration: Fert and his collaborators [19] combined concomitant magnetic force microscopy and Hall resistivity measurements to demonstrate the electrical detection of sub-100 nm skyrmions in a multilayered thin film at room-temperature.

Legrand et al. [20] showed that room temperature antiferromagnetic skyrmions can be stabilized in synthetic antiferromagnets (SAFs), in which perpendicular magnetic anisotropy, antiferromagnetic coupling and chiral order can be adjusted concurrently.

title: Recommended high performance telescope system design for the TianQin project
summary: This paper presents a high-performance telescope system design for the TianQin project, focusing on ultra-stable structure and ultra-low wavefront distortion. The design meets the noise budget requirements for space-based GW detection and can be a good candidate for the TianQin project.
methodology: The methodology involves designing an off-axis four-mirror telescope configuration with a coaxial mirror design based on Seidel aberration theory, eliminating occlusion by making both the field of view and aperture off-axis. A progressive optimization is implemented to decrease wavefront error over the full FOV.
research_outcomes: The final design result shows that the maximum RMS wavefront error is less than λ/300 over the full field of view, meeting the noise budget requirements. The stray light performance of the designed telescope is also demonstrated using commercially optical software ASAP.

title: A comprehensive study of Modulation effects on CMB Polarization
summary: This paper investigates the effects of modulation on Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarization, providing a mathematical explanation for the null result observed in previous studies. The authors show that E mode permits no modulation in general and dipole modulation in particular, with implications for masking and power leakage.
methodology: The paper uses harmonic analysis to study the properties of polarization fields' harmonic coefficients and their behavior under modulation.
research_outcomes: The authors conclude that direct masking in E mode is not possible, and that power leakage is unavoidable upon mask application.

title: Resolve partially the inner disk for Epsilon Eridani
summary: This paper presents mid-infrared imaging observations of the debris disk around Epsilon Eridani, resolving the dust emission in the inner region. The study uses a high angular resolution technique at Mid-Infrared wavelength to investigate the exozodiacal dust of the inner debris disk.
methodology: The authors used mid-infrared imaging observations with the Canaricam/GTC instrument, performing shift-and add on individual savesets or nodsets to improve the Strehl ratio. They also applied a statistical technique called Student t-test to resolve debris disk variances.
research_outcomes: The dust emission around the debris disk is spatially resolved, and the size of the emission is determined. The study confirms the presence of two giant planets in the inner region of the debris disk.

title: Formation of a Quasar Host Galaxy through a Wet Merger
summary: This paper presents high-resolution observations of the molecular gas in the host galaxy of the quasar BRI 1335-0417, located 1.4 billion years after the Big Bang. The study reveals a complex structure and suggests that the galaxy formed through a major, gas-rich merger.
methodology: High-resolution Very Large Array imaging
research_outcomes: The study provides evidence for a wet merger at high redshift related to AGN activity and suggests that such mergers may be responsible for the formation of massive galaxies.

title: The Quasar SDSS J153636.22+044127.0: A Double-Peaked Emitter in a Candidate Binary Black-Hole System
summary: This paper investigates the quasar SDSS J153636.22+044127.0, which exhibits double-peaked emission lines and is proposed to be a binary black hole system. The authors use a circular Keplerian disk model to fit the Hα and Hβ profiles, finding that the system is consistent with being both a double-peaked emitter and a binary black hole system.
methodology: The authors used a circular Keplerian disk model to fit the Hα and Hβ profiles of the quasar SDSS J153636.22+044127.0, taking into account the Narrow Line Region (NLR) and Broad Line Region (BLR).
research_outcomes: The authors found that the system is consistent with being both a double-peaked emitter and a binary black hole system.

title: Hydrogen molecular ions for improved determination of fundamental constants
summary: This paper proposes a new route towards an independent determination of the Rydberg constant, nuclear radii and nucleus-to-electron mass ratios using high-resolution laser spectroscopy of hydrogen molecular ions. The method relies on Doppler-free two-photon transitions in ensembles of trapped and sympathetically cooled HMI, allowing for improved accuracy by several orders of magnitude.
methodology: The paper proposes a new approach to determine fundamental constants using high-resolution laser spectroscopy of hydrogen molecular ions. The method involves identifying suitable rovibrational transitions, computing the dependence of transition frequencies on fundamental constants, and evaluating the uncertainty of those measurements and related theoretical predictions.
research_outcomes: The paper proposes a new route towards an independent determination of the Rydberg constant, nuclear radii and nucleus-to-electron mass ratios. The method relies on Doppler-free two-photon transitions in ensembles of trapped and sympathetically cooled HMI.

title: Chiral violations from one-loop domain wall fermions
summary: This paper studies chiral symmetry breaking in domain-wall fermions using lattice perturbation theory. The authors calculate the residual mass and other matrix elements measuring the breaking of chiral symmetry, and find that the truncation of domain-wall fermions at finite N s generates a nonvanishing residual mass already at the tree level.
methodology: Lattice perturbation theory
research_outcomes: The authors found that the residual mass and other matrix elements measuring the breaking of chiral symmetry are affected by the truncation of domain-wall fermions at finite N s.

title: Light-mass Bragg cavity polaritons in planar quantum dot lattices
summary: This paper investigates the exciton-polariton modes of a quantum dot lattice embedded in a planar optical cavity, focusing on Bragg polariton modes obtained by tuning the exciton and the cavity modes into resonance at high symmetry points of the Brillouin Zone. The authors exploit the newly gained opportunity of growing artificial structures with spatial periodicity comparable to the wavelength of the confined quasiparticle, the exciton in their case.
methodology: Theoretical investigation using a Hamiltonian for the QD lattice interacting with two-dimensional photon modes
research_outcomes: The authors find that the polariton dispersion is entirely determined by the coupling between the exciton in the dots and two-dimensional photons, leading to in-plane effective masses which can be exceptionally small.

title: Ultralight Dark Matter Detection with Mechanical Quantum Sensors
summary: This paper explores the use of mechanical quantum sensors to detect ultralight dark matter candidates. The authors propose an array of sensors as a scalable and sensitive detection method, leveraging the high force sensitivities and rapid scalability in mass of these devices.
methodology: The authors employ a combination of theoretical modeling and numerical simulations to study the interaction between ultralight dark matter candidates and mechanical sensors. They use natural units and quote experimentally-relevant numbers in SI units for ease of comparison with experimental work.
research_outcomes: The paper demonstrates that an array of mechanical sensors can enhance the detection reach by a factor of at least √Ndet, and as fast as Ndet, in the case of correlated, 'Heisenberg-limited' readout. The authors also propose ultralight DM detection as a nearer-term goal achievable with just a few mechanical sensors operating at noise levels around the standard quantum limit.

title: The Discovery of Herbig-Haro Objects in LDN 673
summary: This paper reports the discovery of twelve faint Herbig-Haro objects in the region of LDN 673 using a novel color-composite imaging method. The research focuses on understanding star formation in the Aquila clouds, but does not involve any machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The authors used a color-composite imaging method to reveal faint Hα emission in complex environments, and followed up with [S II] observations for confirmation.
research_outcomes: The discovery of twelve new HH objects provides evidence for star formation in the Aquila clouds, implying a larger T Tauri population in this region.

title: Terahertz Imaging Progress at Capital Normal University
summary: This paper presents the progress on terahertz imaging technology at Capital Normal University, focusing on active and passive imaging methods. The research aims to improve imaging speed and resolution for non-destructive testing and security inspection applications.
methodology: The methodology involves using THz time-domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS) and a CO2-laser-pumped terahertz coherent source for active imaging, while passive imaging uses low-frequency radiometers to detect the point-to-point beam-scanned THz signal.
research_outcomes: The research outcomes include improved imaging speed and resolution for both active and passive THz imaging methods. The study also presents a new method for wave front imaging using a Hartmann plate.

title: The mass of the Delta resonance in a finite volume: fourth-order calculation
summary: This paper calculates the self-energy of the Delta (1232) resonance in a finite volume using chiral effective field theory with explicit spin-3/2 fields. The calculations are performed up-to-and-including fourth order in the small scale expansion and yield an explicit parameterization of the energy spectrum of the interacting pion-nucleon pair in a finite box in terms of both the quark mass and the box size L.
methodology: Chiral effective field theory with explicit spin-3/2 fields
research_outcomes: The paper provides an explicit formula for the finite-volume corrections for the unstable ∆, which can be used in the analysis of the lattice data; it also performs a fit of the obtained expressions to the most recent available data at different quark masses, taking into account finite-volume corrections.
sources_of_inspiration: Chiral effective field theory with explicit spin-3/2 fields

title: Quantum-Electrodynamical Time-Dependent Density Functional Theory. I. A Gaussian Atomic Basis Implementation
summary: This paper presents a quantum-electrodynamical time-dependent density functional theory (QED-TDDFT) implementation using a Gaussian atomic basis. The authors examine the effects of dipole self-energy, rotating wave approximation, and Tamm-Dancoff approximation on QED-TDDFT eigenstates in an optical cavity.
methodology: The authors use a modified matrix formulation of linear-response quantum electrodynamical time-dependent density functional theory (QED-TDDFT) to derive a symmetric TDDFT-Pauli-Fierz Hamiltonian for coupling molecules and cavity photons.
research_outcomes: The study examines the effects of various approximations on QED-TDDFT eigenstates in an optical cavity, with implications for polariton chemistry.
sources_of_inspiration: Rubio and coworkers' formulation of quantum-electrodynamical time-dependent density functional theory (QED-TDDFT)
